title-group.article-title: Effect of high hydrostatic pressure on overall quality parameters of watermelon juice

article-meta.aff: 1School of Food and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Technology and Business University, China
2Vegetable Research Center, Beijing Academy of Agriculture and Forestry Sciences, China
4College of Food Science and Nutritional Engineering, China Agricultural University, China

author-notes.corresp: Y Liu, School of Food and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Technology and Business University, Beijing 100048, China Email: liuyecau@126.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: High hydrostatic pressure as a kind of non-thermal processing might maintain the quality of thermo-sensitive watermelon juice. So, the effect of high hydrostatic pressure treatment on enzymes and quality of watermelon juice was investigated. After high hydrostatic pressure treatment, the activities of polyphenol oxidase, peroxidase, and pectin methylesterase of juice decreased significantly with the pressure (P < 0.05). Inactivation of polyphenol oxidase and peroxidase could be fitted by two-fraction model and that of pectin methylesterase could be described by first-order reaction model. Titratable acidity, pH, and total soluble solid of juice did not change significantly (P > 0.05). No significant difference was observed in lycopene and total phenolics after high hydrostatic pressure treatment when compared to the control (P > 0.05). Cloudiness and viscosity increased with pressure (P < 0.05) but did not change significantly with treatment time (P > 0.05). a*- and b*-value both unchanged after high hydrostatic pressure treatment (P > 0.05) while L*-value increased but the values had no significant difference among treated juices. Browning degree after high hydrostatic pressure treatment decreased with increase in pressure and treatment time (P < 0.05). Through the comparison of total color difference values, high hydrostatic pressure had little effect on color of juice. The results of this study demonstrated the efficacy of high hydrostatic pressure in inactivating enzymes and maintaining the quality of watermelon juice.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Watermelon juice is becoming more and more popular because of its fresh flavor and taste. In addition, watermelon juice can provide potential health benefits and reduce incidence of coronary heart disease and cancer due to the presence of some phenolics, vitamin C, and a large amount of lycopene (Edwards et al., 2003; Fraser and Bramley, 2004; Gil et al., 2006; Giovannucci, 2002; Perkins-Veazie et al., 2001). However, the undesirable changes on the sensory quality are induced by enzymes and microorganisms in the watermelon juice without processing due to the low acidity and high water activity of these fruit. Hence, sterilization is a necessary procedure in the watermelon juice processing. Thermal treatment is a traditional effective method to destroy microorganisms and inactivate enzymes in foods (Lambert, 2003; Mann et al., 2001; Zanoni et al., 2003). Nevertheless, watermelon is a kind of thermo-sensitive fruit in which sensory and nutritional properties will be destroyed by heat inevitably. For this reason, the increasing demand for fresh-like juice has resulted in a growing interest in novel non-thermal processes such as high hydrostatic pressure (HHP). It was proved that HHP could inactivate pathogenic microorganisms and enzymes without significantly destroying thermo-sensitive nutrients, texture, color, and flavor of foods (Basak and Ramaswamy, 1996; Carreno et al., 2011; Krebbers et al., 2003).

HHP can inactivate microorganisms by inactivating key enzymes, lowering pH, and altering membrane functionalities of cell (Farr, 1990; Hoover et al., 1989; Shimada et al., 1993). Meanwhile, HHP can change enzymic activity by changing the conformation of enzyme protein (Mozhaev et al., 1996; Scirè et al., 2010). HHP treatment inactivated pectin methylesterase (PME) in orange juice effectively and the pressure-hold inactivation of PME followed first-order rate kinetics (Basak and Ramaswamy, 1996). HHP (150–350 MPa) combined with mild heat (20–30 °C) treatment produced significant reduction of PME, peroxidase (POD), and polyphenol oxidase (PPO) in various degree (10–32.5%) in tomato puree, while some activation were observed at other treatment conditions (Hernandez and Cano, 1998). PME activity inactivated more than 99% after high pressure processing (HPP) (one pulse, 700 MPa, 30 s, and 90 °C) treatment (Krebbers et al., 2003).

Food quality was another aspect to be focused on while the microorganism and enzymes were inactivated by HHP treatment. There have been relatively few studies about the physical, chemical, and sensory quality of liquid foods following HHP treatment. Studies on yellow passion fruit juice showed that HHP treatment (300 MPa and 25 °C for 5 min) caused no significant modifications in compounds responsible for aroma, flavor, and consistency (Laboissière et al., 2007). The main attributes of beer, such as ethanol content, extract, and pH were not affected by HHP treatment while color, chill haze, protein sensitivity, and bitterness changed (Buzrul et al., 2005). And the content of α- and β-carotene were relatively stable at the combined process of HHP and mild heat (Kim et al., 2001). In addition, total pectin content, viscosity, free glutamic acid, and color (aL/bL) in tomato juice increased with increasing pressure after HHP treatment, and n-hexanal, one of the most important components responsible for the typical fresh flavor of tomato, showed a remarkable increase regardless of treatment time and pressure (Porretta et al., 1995).

So far, there is little knowledge on the application of HHP treatment on watermelon juice. The objective of this study was to investigate the effect of HHP treatment on the activity of endogenous enzymes and overall quality parameters of watermelon juice.

sec.title: Preparation of watermelon juice
sec.p: Watermelons (Jingling) were harvested maturely in Yanqing farm. The watermelons were washed, peeled, and crushed with a blender (Philips, HR2860, Zhuhai, China). The homogenous solution was filtrated by gauzes (60 mesh size). The filtrate was subjected to the following treatments.

sec.title: HHP process system
sec.p: HHP treatment was carried out using a hydrostatic pressurization unit (HHP-650, Baotou Hefa Co., Ltd., Inner Mongolia, China) with a cylinder 11 cm in inner diameter, 30 cm in height, and a capacity of 2.8 L. Distilled water was used as the pressure-transmitting fluid. The rate of pressure increase was about 120 MPa/min and the pressure release was immediate. The treatment time reported in this study did not include the pressure increase and release time. The temperature in the pressure vessel rose from 25 °C to 33 °C during coming up to 600 MPa by compression heating. Then the temperature decreased to 25 °C for about 5 min during pressure holding.

sec.title: HHP treatment of watermelon juice
sec.p: Approximately 200 mL of watermelon juice was transferred into a sterile polyethylene bag (90 µm thick) and heat-sealed under vacuum. The bags were placed into the pressure vessel and treated at 200, 400, and 600 MPa for 5, 15, 30, 45, and 60 min, respectively. Controls were not pressurized. The experiment was carried out at room temperature.

sec.title: Determination of PPO and POD activity
sec.p: The watermelon juice was stirred with 1% polyvinylpolypyrrolidone (Sigma–Aldrich Co., Shanghai, China) and 1% Triton X-100 at 4 °C for 1 h and centrifuged at 10,000× g (Sigma, 3–18 sartorius, Germany) and 4 °C for 20 min. The supernates were prepared for the assay of PPO and POD activity.
PPO activity was assayed according to the method described by Duangmal and Apenten (1999) with minor modifications.

POD activity was assayed according to the method described by Onsa et al. (2004) with minor modifications. The residual activities of PPO and POD were calculated according to equation (1).
(1)Residual activity=Enzyme activity treatedwith HHP×100%Enzyme activity before HHP

sec.title: Determination of PME activity
sec.p: The activity of PME was measured at pH 7.5 and 30 °C according to the method proposed by Kimball (1991).

sec.title: Kinetics analysis
sec.p:
Inactivation kinetics of PPO and POD from the watermelon juice was fitted by a two-fraction model (Castro et al., 2006; Nunes et al., 2006). This model took into account the existence of two isoenzymes, labile, and stable fraction. The stable fraction was more resistant to temperature and/or pressure than the labile one. Both fractions were considered to be inactivated according to the first-order model, being independent of each other. There was a fast inactivation period followed by a decelerated decay, the total activity decay was described by equation (2).
(2)A=ALexp(-kLt)+ASexp(-kSt) where AL and AS refer to the activity of the labile and stable fractions in relation to total enzyme inactivation, respectively; kL and kS are the inactivation rate constants of the labile and stable fraction (min−1), respectively.

Inactivation kinetics of PME is evaluated by the first-order reaction (Basak and Ramaswamy, 1996), as equation (3).
(3)log[AtA0]=[k2.303]t where At is the residual enzymatic activity at time t; A0 the initial enzymatic activity; and k the reaction rate constant (min−1) at given pressure and temperature. The value of k was obtained from the regression of log [At/A0] versus time as slope/2.303.

The decimal reduction time (D value) defined as the treatment time needed for 90% inactivation of initial activity of PPO at a given condition was obtained.
(4)D=2.303k

sec.title: Determination of pH
sec.p: The pH value of the sample was measured at 25 °C with a Thermo Orion 868 pH meter (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc., MA, USA) which was calibrated with pH 4.0 and 7.0 buffer.

sec.title: Determination of titratable acidity (TA)
sec.p: Ten mL of watermelon juice was titrated using standardized 0.02 M NaOH to the phenolphthalein end point (pH = 8.1) (Rodrigo et al., 2003).

sec.title: Determination of browning degree (BD)
sec.p: Juice BD was evaluated using a spectrophotometric method described by Roig et al. (1999).

sec.title: Determination of total soluble solid (TSS)
sec.p: Total soluble solid of watermelon juice was determined as Brix using a PAL-α portable digital Refractometer (ATAGO, Japan) at 25 °C (Wang et al., 2006).

sec.title: Determination of lycopene content
sec.p: The content of lycopene was measured spectrophotometrically using the methods of Sadler et al. (1990) with modifications. Lycopene content was calculated with the standard linear curve: Y = 0.0154 + 0.244X (R2 = 0.998) of lycopene solution in hexane in concentrations from 0.5 to 5 µg/mL.

sec.title: Determination of color
sec.p:
Color assessment was conducted at 25 °C using a color difference meter (Konica Minolta CR-200, Japan) in the reflectance mode. Hunter L*-, a*-, and b*-value of juices was measured and the total color difference (ΔE) was calculated as
(5)ΔE=[(L*-L0*)2+(a*-a0*)2+(b*-b0*)2]1/2 where L* – lightness of treated juice, L*0 – lightness of the control, a* – redness of treated juice, b* – yellowness of treated juice, a*0 – redness of the control, and b*0 – yellowness of the control (Gui et al., 2006).

sec.title: Determination of total phenolic content
sec.p: Total phenolics in the watermelon juice were determined with Folin–Ciocalteu reagent by the method of Singleton and Rossi (1965) using pyrogallol as a standard.

sec.title: Determination of cloud
sec.p: The cloud of watermelon juice was determined using a 1900C portable turbidimeter (HACH, USA) and was reported as nephelometric turbidity units (NTUs) (Reiter et al., 2003). Watermelon juice diluted with distilled water (1:15 V/V) was measured in a 20 mL quartz cuvette.

sec.title: Determination of viscosity
sec.p: The viscosity of watermelon juice was determined using an AR-1500 rheometer (TA Instruments, Waters Co., Ltd., Surrey, Great Britain). One mL of watermelon juice was applied at each measurement with 25 °C controlled by circulating water in a thermostatic system.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Duncan’s multiple range tests were carried out using the software SAS (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA). The ANOVA test was performed for all experimental run, to determine the significance at 95% confidence interval. All experiments were performed in triplicates.

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on PPO and POD activity of watermelon juice
sec.p:
The effect of HHP treatment on PPO and POD residual activity of watermelon juice is shown in Figures 1 and 2. The residual activities of both enzymes decreased with the treatment time and pressure. At each pressure, the residual activity decreased drastically during the initial stage and slowly after 5 min with increase in treatment time. At each treatment time, the residual activity of PPO and POD decreased with increase in pressure. The residual activities of both enzymes were 12.3% and 57.6% at 30 MPa for 60 min. Figure 1.
Inactivation of PPO of watermelon juice by HHP treatment of different pressures at room temperature. All data represent means ±SD, n = 3. HHP: high hydrostatic pressure; PPO: polyphenol oxidase.
Figure 2.
Inactivation of POD of watermelon juice by HHP treatment of different pressures at room temperature. All data represent means ±SD, n = 3. HHP: high hydrostatic pressure; POD: peroxidase.

As presented in Table 1, the inactivation curves of PPO and POD were well fitted to two-fraction model (R2 ≥ 0.959). It suggested that two isoenzymes exist in PPO and POD of watermelon juice. One isoenzyme was sensitive to pressure and the other was stable. When pressure was applied, the liable one could be inactivated easily but the stable one could not. The biphasic kinetic parameters of the decimal values D of PPO and POD were closely related to pressure levels and higher pressures resulted in lower DL. DS values of PPO and POD were both far larger than DL in Table 2, confirming that the stable fraction is more resistant to pressure than labile fraction. DL values of PPO were similar with that of POD, but DS values of PPO were far lower than that of POD, suggesting that the liable fraction of both enzymes have the similar susceptibility to pressure and the stable fraction of POD has the lower susceptibility than that of PPO. The similar inactivation effect was shown in POD of carrot extract juice by HHP treatment (Soysal et al., 2004). However, the different phenomenon presented in studies on PPOs of red raspberries and PODs of green peas, strawberries, in which residual activities of PPOs and PODs decreased linearly by HHP treatment (Garcia-Palazon et al., 2004; Quaglia et al., 1996; Terefe et al., 2010). The discrepancy among these investigations resulted from the characteristics of enzymes of different sources and treatment systems. Table 1.
Kinetic parameters for inactivation of PPO and POD in watermelon juice by HHP treatment
Pressure (MPa) PPO POD
kL (min−1) kS (min−1) DL (min) DS (min) R2 (P < 0.05) kL (min−1) kS (min−1) DL (min) DS (min) R2 (P < 0.05)
200 0.416 0.004 5.53 544.44 0.996 0.425 0.002 5.42 1225.00 0.959
400 0.434 0.008 5.31 293.00 0.998 0.501 0.001 4.60 2093.64 0.991
600 0.467 0.004 4.93 639.72 0.998 0.912 0.001 2.53 5234.09 0.994
HHP: high hydrostatic pressure, PPO: polyphenoloxidase,and POD: peroxidase.
kL and kS: inactivation rate constants of the labile and stable fraction, respectively and DL and DS: decimal reduction time of the labile and stable fraction, respectively.
Table 2.
Kinetic parameters for inactivation of PME in watermelon juice by HHP treatment
Pressure (MPa) k (min−1) D (min) R2 (P < 0.05)
200 0.002 1250.27 0.988
400 0.004 619.09 0.965
600 0.017 136.03 0.977
HHP: high hydrostatic pressure and PME: pectin methylesterase.
k: inactivation rate constants and D: decimal reduction time.

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on PME activity of watermelon juice
sec.p:
The effect of HHP treatment on residual activity of PME of watermelon juice is shown in Figure 3. It also decreased with the treatment time and pressure (except 200 MPa for 30 and 45 min, 600 MPa for 15 and 30 min). In general, the residual activity of PME decreased linearly during 0–60 min by HHP treatment. And the minimum of PME residual acitivity was 23.2% at 600 MPa for 60 min. This result might be due to two possibilities. Firstly, PME in watermelon juice might have only one existing form; Secondly, the proportion of liable isoenzyme of PME might be too great to inactivate during 0–60 min completely. Figure 3.
Inactivation of PME of watermelon juice by HHP treatment of different pressures at room temperature. All data represent means ±SD, n = 3. HHP: high hydrostatic pressure; PME: pectin methylesterase.

As presented in Table 2, the inactivation curves of PME were well fitted to first-order reaction model (R2 ≥ 0.965). D values decreased drastically from 1250.27 to 136.01 min when pressure increased from 200 to 600 MPa. The result in this study was in agreement with that of PME in orange juice inactivated by high pressure (Shellhammer and Nienaber, 2001). However, the inactivation of PME in most of previous studies could not be fitted by first-order reaction model. Inactivation of PME from strawberries and bananas by high pressure could be all described by a fractional-conversion model (Ly-Nguyen et al., 2002a, 2002b).

The decrease of enzymatic activity was attributed to the change of protein structure. At relatively low temperature, covalent bonds were almost unaffected by high pressure, hence the primary structure remained intact. And hydrogen bonds were ruptured at high pressure, which contributed to the change of secondary structure of enzymatic protein. Tertiary structure which maintained chiefly by hydrophobic and ionic interactions changed in excess of 200 MPa (Hendrickx et al., 1998). On the contrary, some enzymes were activated by HHP treatment. An activation of PPO at presures between 200 and 500 MPa (Asaka and Hayashi, 1991). POD in strawberry puree was activated by HHP treatment between 280 and 400 MPa for 15 min at 20 °C (Cano et al., 1997). They also observed an activation of PME in orange juice treated by HHP between 200 and 400 MPa at room temperature. All these activation of enzyme activity might be attributed to binding of isoenzymes with the added chemical reactive or partial denaturation to released isoenzymes with higher enzyme activity.

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on pH and TA of watermelon juice
sec.p:
The effect of HHP treatment on the pH and TA of watermelon juice is presented in Table 3. The initial TA and pH of juice was 0.69 mg/L and 5.83, respectively. After HHP treatment, both values did not change significantly (P > 0.05). This result was in accordance with that of Valencia and Navel orange juice, carrot juice, and diced tomatoes under HPP treatment (Bull et al., 2004; Park et al., 2002; Shook et al., 2001). However, some investigations showed the different trends. pH of Tommy Atkins mangoes increased and TA decreased slightly after HPP of 300 and 600 MPa (Boynton et al., 2002). On the contrary, pH of high-pressure-treated milk during cheese-making decreased with treatment time (Pandey et al., 2003). The change of pH was related to protein in milk. Heat effect induced by high pressure leaded to increase in temperature of milk, milk proteins decomposed into amino acid, which resulted in increase in pH. While in this study, enzymes related to pectin hydrolyzing were inactivated by HHP treatment. It prevented the production of pectic acid, avoided increase in pH. Table 3.
Effect of HHP treatment of different pressures at room temperature on the quality parameters of watermelon juice
Pressure (MPa) Time (min) pH TA (mg/L) TSS (°Brix) Lycopene content (µg/mL) Total phenolic content (µg/mL) Viscosity (mPa·s)

Within the same column, *represent a significant difference (P < 0.05).

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on BD of watermelon juice
sec.p:
The influence of HHP treatment on BD of watermelon juice is shown in Figure 4. The initial BD of juice was 1.102. The BD value of the HHP treated watermelon juice decreased significantly (P < 0.05) as compared to the control. The BD of watermelon juice after HHP treatment decreased with increase in pressure and treatment time which dropped to 0.393 at 30 MPa for 60 min. Hence, HHP treatment was an effective method to control browning of watermelon juice. Figure 4.
Effect of HHP treatment of different pressures at room temperature on BD of watermelon juice. All data represent means ±SD, n = 3. BD: browning degree; HHP: high hydrostatic pressure.

The browning of watermelon juice included non-enzymatic and enzymatic browning. Maillard reaction was one of the most important processes of non-enzymatic browning. It was initiated by a condensation between the carbonyl group of a reducing sugar and an amino compound to form the Amadori rearrangement product (ARP). The final products of the reaction, so-called melanoidins, were brown polymers. High pressure inhibited the rate of Maillard browning because the decomposition of ARP had a positive volume of activation (Isaacs and Coulson, 1996). In addition, PPO and POD were the key enzymes closely related to the browning in watermelon juice. HHP treatment could inactivate PPO and POD activity effectively and their residual activity decreased with the pressure and treatment time increasing which was consistent with BD variation. Hence, HHP treatment restrained browning of watermelon juice by inactivating PPO and POD activity.

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on TSS of watermelon juice
sec.p: The influence of HHP treatment on TSS of watermelon juice is presented in Table 3. The initial TSS value of juice was 9.55°Brix. After HHP treatment, TSS showed fluctuations but did not change significantly compared to the control (P > 0.05). TSS of juice include sugar, organic acids, and other soluble components. Usually, soluble components may combine with other insoluble substances decreasing soluble solids. HHP treatment could inactivate enzymes related to converting between soluble and insoluble solids, so TSS of juice after HHP treatment did not change. Similar result was observed for high pressure treated guava juice (Yen and Lin, 1998). However, TSS may increase due to insoluble components in juice dissolving after heat treatment. Hence, HHP had better effect in maintaining TSS of watermelon juice.

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on lycopene and total phenolic content of watermelon juice
sec.p: The effect of HHP treatment on the lycopene and total phenolic content of watermelon juice is presented in Table 3. The initial lycopene and total phenolic content was 62.56 and 16.17 µg/mL, respectively. After HHP treatment, both content did not change significantly with increase in pressure and treatment time (P > 0.05).

In lycopene solution, pressure under 400 MPa did not affect the content of total lycopene, while pressure of 500 and 600 MPa caused significant losses compared to the control. And in tomato puree, there were no significant differences between samples treated by high pressure under 600 MPa (except for 500 MPa) and control (Qiu et al., 2006). Report showed that after HHP treatment all-trans lycopene might transform to cis-isomers which was better absorbed in the body than the all-trans isomers but in an unstable, energy-rich situation (Shi and Le Maguer, 2000). Hence, the change of lycopene in watermelon juice might be not embodied in the content but in the isomerization, which need be further studied.

Similarly, combined high pressure–mild temperature processing did not affect the total polyphenol content of strawberries significantly (Terefe et al., 2009). And the content of total phenolics of strawberry and blackberry purees also did not change after HHP treatment of 400 and 500 MPa, while it increased significantly at 600 MPa (Patras et al., 2009). The different results between this study and Patras et al. might derive from the different food system. HHP treatment of 600 MPa increased extractability of some antioxidant components from intact cell in purees which phenolics existed in. While in the watermelon juice phenolics had already dispersed in juice, high pressure did not affect its content. Moreover, PPO activity was inactivated by HHP treatment, phenolics in juice would not be consumed basically.

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on cloudiness of watermelon juice
sec.p:
The influence of HHP treatment on cloudiness of watermelon juice is shown in Figure 5. The initial cloudiness of juice was 49.85 NTU. After HHP treatment, the cloudiness of juice increased with increase in pressure compared to the control (P < 0.05), but it did not change significantly with increase in treatment time under the same pressure (P > 0.05). It indicated that pressure was more effective to increase cloudiness than treatment time. Similarly, Cloud stabilization of orange juice increased after HPP of 600–900 MPa for 1 or 10 min (Goodner et al., 1999). In juice system, pectin was an important factor impacting the cloud. Total pectin content was obtained by summing the pectic acids, pectates, and protopectin (Porretta et al., 1995). Although pectic acids content did not change due to PME being inactivated by HHP treatment basically, it was combined with metal ion (e.g. Mg2+, Ca2+) to form pectates. Pectates suspending in juice system increased the cloudiness. In addition, the enzymatic browning induced by PPO and POD which was not completely inactivated by HHP treatment generated the water-insoluble pigment. The pigment particles dispersing in juice also increased the cloudiness. Thirdly, the structure of protein in watermelon juice changed after HHP treatment, more binding sites exposed. Thus, it was easier that the protein combined with polyphenol to form the complexes. They growed up to colloidal particles and improved the cloudiness. Figure 5.
Effect of HHP treatment of different pressures at room temperature on cloudiness of watermelon juice. All data represent means ±SD, n = 3. HHP: high hydrostatic pressure.

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on viscosity of watermelon juice
sec.p: The influence of HHP treatment on viscosity of watermelon juice is presented in Table 3. Usually, the shear rate of human tongue while drinking was between 30 and 40 s-1 approximately. So, the viscosity at 31.62 s-1 of HHP treatment of different pressure and treatment time at room temperature was recorded and listed in Table 3. The initial viscosity of juice was 1.57 mPa·s. The viscosity of juice increased significantly after HHP treatment (P < 0.05), while it had no significant difference among the treated juice (P > 0.05). One hand, HHP treatment accelerates protopectin in pulp transforming into water-soluble pectin. The other hand, the activity of polygalacturonase decreased leaded to reducing end group of pectin decreasing and degree of polymerization increasing after HHP treatment. The combined action of both sides resulted in viscosity of watermelon juice increasing. With the same result, HPP at ambient temperature (1 × 2 min, 300, 500, and 700 MPa, 20 °C) improved the viscosity of tomato puree at a shear-rate of 13.6 s-1 (Krebbers et al., 2003).

sec.title: Effect of HHP treatment on the color of watermelon juice
sec.p:
The influence of HHP treatment on color of watermelon juice is presented in Table 4. The initial L*-, a*-, and b*-value of juice were 26.37, 18.80, and 6.61, respectively. After HHP treatment, L*-value increased but the value did not change with increase in pressure and treatment time; a*- and b*-value had no significant difference compared to the control (P < 0.05). L*-value increasing mainly resulted from decrease in BD after HHP treatment. BD of juice decreased with increase in pressure and treatment time, but L*-value had no similar regularity which implied that BD was not the only factor to affect L*-value. Lycopene is the main source of red color of watermelon (Perkins-Veazie et al., 2001). HHP treatment did not affect the content of lycopene, so a*- and b*-values were stable. Similarly, the color of tomato puree remained unchanged after HHP treatment of 700 MPa for 60 min (Rodrigo et al., 2007). While a*-value increased significantly after HHP treatment of 400–600 MPa in tomato and carrot puree (Patras et al., 2009). It was because that the content of carotenoid and lycopene increased which was induced by the extraction of high pressure. On the contrary, a*-value for strawberry and blackberry purees after HHP treatment of 400–600 MPa were significantly lower than for the control (Patras et al., 2009). In strawberry and blackberry, anthocyanins were the pigment responsible for the red color, the content of Py3gl and Cygl were positively correlated with a*-value. Although, the content of total anthocyanins did not change, the content of Py3gl and Cygl must change by HHP treatment. Table 4.
Effect of HHP treatment of different pressures at room temperature on the color of watermelon juice
Pressure (MPa) Time (min) L a b ΔE
CK 26.37 ± 0.35* 18.80 ± 1.05 6.61 ± 0.33 0.00
200 15 28.33 ± 0.51 18.39 ± 0.65 6.69 ± 0.16 2.00
30 28.21 ± 0.12 18.57 ± 0.57 6.65 ± 0.11 1.85
45 28.48 ± 0.17 18.82 ± 0.33 6.58 ± 0.06 2.11
60 28.32 ± 0.30 18.79 ± 0.12 6.60 ± 0.17 1.95
400 15 28.52 ± 0.26 18.66 ± 0.37 6.52 ± 0.19 2.16
30 28.43 ± 0.47 18.85 ± 0.18 6.68 ± 0.35 2.06
45 28.47 ± 0.43 18.72 ± 0.39 6.63 ± 0.21 2.10
60 28.30 ± 0.28 18.69 ± 0.28 6.53 ± 0.59 1.93
600 15 28.22 ± 0.19 18.77 ± 0.13 6.56 ± 0.10 1.85
30 28.39 ± 0.38 18.81 ± 0.45 6.67 ± 0.09 2.02
45 28.28 ± 0.31 18.85 ± 0.11 6.61 ± 0.28 1.91
60 28.37 ± 0.46 18.76 ± 0.08 6.53 ± 0.06 2.00
ΔE: total color difference and HHP: high hydrostatic pressure.
Value are means, n = 3.
Within the same column, *represent a significant difference (P < 0.05).

ΔE of watermelon juice was calculated according to equation (5). A noticeable difference can be visualized between two colors when they differ by ΔE > 2–3.5 (Krapfenbauer et al., 2006). It could be seen that ΔE after HHP treatment of most conditions were lower than two, indicating that HPP could maintain the original color of juice well.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: PPO, POD, and PME of watermelon juice were inactivated after HHP treatment. And the inactivation of PPO and POD were fitted well by two-fraction model and that of PME could be described by first-order reaction model. TA, pH, and TSS of juice did not change significantly (P > 0.05). BD after HHP treatment decreased with increase in pressure and treatment time which dropped to 0.393 at 30 MPa for 60 min (P < 0.05). No significant difference was observed in lycopene and total phenolics after HHP treatment when compared to the control (P > 0.05). The cloudiness of juice increased with increase in pressure (P < 0.05), but it did not change significantly with treatment time under the same pressure (P > 0.05). The viscosity increased after HHP treatment, while there were no significant difference among the treated juices (P > 0.05). L*-value increased but the values had no significant difference among treated juices; a*- and b*-value had no significant difference compared to the control (P > 0.05). Anyhow, HHP treatment could inactivate enzymatic activity effectively and maintain the quality of watermelon juice better.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by Talents Funds of Organization Department, Beijing Committee of CPC (2011D005003000007).
